Express gratitude regularly for your partner's qualities and efforts
Stand up for your partner in social situations

behaviors.name: Autonomy
behaviors.definition: Maintaining a healthy sense of individual identity, interests, friendships, and personal space within the relationship, while also being committed to the partnership. The ability to be 'two whole people' rather than 'two halves making a whole'.
examples: Maintaining personal hobbies and interests that are separate from the relationship
Having friendships and social connections independent of the partner
Making some decisions independently without needing partner approval for everything
Spending time alone comfortably without interpreting it as rejection of the partner
healthy_indicators: Both partners have a clear sense of who they are outside the relationship
Time apart is seen as healthy and normal, not threatening
Individual goals and growth are encouraged and supported
Neither partner needs the other to complete their sense of self
unhealthy_indicators: One or both partners have given up all individual interests and friendships
Wanting to do anything alone is interpreted as a rejection of the relationship
Individual identity has been subsumed by the couple identity
Anxiety or guilt about having independent thoughts, opinions, or activities
behaviors.frequency_note: A healthy balance of togetherness and autonomy is unique to each couple and may shift over time. What matters is that both partners feel the balance serves their wellbeing.
common_contexts: Planning how to spend free time
Navigating different interests and social circles
Making personal decisions about career, health, or self-development
Managing the transition to living together or becoming parents
potential_impact: Individuals bring more energy, interest, and richness to the relationship
Prevents the suffocation and resentment that can come from excessive togetherness
Maintains each partner's mental health and sense of self
Creates a relationship of choice rather than dependency
communication_tips: Communicate your need for alone time or independent activities as a positive, not a rejection
Show genuine interest in your partner's independent activities
Encourage each other to pursue personal growth and goals
Discuss what balance of togetherness and separateness works for both of you

subcategories.name: Boundary Issues
subcategories.description: Problematic patterns where personal limits are either absent, persistently violated, or used in harmful ways.

behaviors.name: Enmeshment
behaviors.definition: An unhealthy blurring of boundaries between partners where individual identities become merged, independence is lost, and the couple functions as a single fused unit rather than two connected individuals. Emotional states, opinions, and decisions become inseparable.
examples: Feeling unable to have a thought, opinion, or feeling that differs from your partner's
Having no friendships, hobbies, or activities that do not include the partner
Needing to be together constantly and feeling intense anxiety at any separation
Making every decision jointly, including minor personal choices like what to wear or eat
healthy_indicators: Recognising the need for individual identity within the relationship
Gradually rebuilding independent interests and connections
Tolerating the discomfort of separateness as a growth edge
Supporting each other's individuality rather than feeling threatened by it
unhealthy_indicators: Complete loss of individual identity; unable to say where one partner ends and the other begins
Any expression of separateness is experienced as betrayal or abandonment
Third parties (friends, family, therapists) are seen as threats to the unit
Neither partner can regulate their emotions independently; each depends entirely on the other
behaviors.frequency_note: Intense closeness is normal in early relationship stages ('honeymoon phase'). Enmeshment becomes problematic when it persists and prevents healthy individuation.
common_contexts: In relationships where one or both partners have anxious attachment
When codependent patterns from family of origin are replicated
After traumatic experiences that increase need for security
In cultures or families that strongly prioritise togetherness over individuality
potential_impact: Loss of personal identity, goals, and growth
Extreme difficulty functioning independently if the relationship ends
Suffocation and resentment when needs for individuality inevitably arise
Children in enmeshed family systems struggle to develop healthy autonomy
communication_tips: Begin with small steps towards independence: a solo walk, an evening with a friend
Practise having and expressing opinions that differ from your partner's in low-stakes situations
Reframe individuality as strengthening the relationship, not weakening it
Consider individual therapy to develop a stronger sense of self

behaviors.name: Boundary Violations
behaviors.definition: Consistently crossing, dismissing, or ignoring a partner's clearly communicated personal limits, demonstrating a lack of respect for their autonomy, comfort, and right to say no.
examples: Continuing to raise a topic a partner has explicitly said they need a break from discussing
Reading a partner's journal, messages, or emails after being told this is not acceptable
Sharing private information about the partner that they asked to be kept confidential
Pressuring a partner to engage in activities they have clearly said no to
healthy_indicators: Respecting stated boundaries even when you disagree with them
Asking permission before engaging in actions that affect a partner's personal space or privacy
Accepting 'no' gracefully without argument, sulking, or punishment
Discussing boundary disagreements respectfully and seeking compromise where appropriate
unhealthy_indicators: Dismissing boundaries as unreasonable, controlling, or unnecessary
Repeatedly crossing the same boundary despite being told it is not acceptable
Framing boundary violations as expressions of love or care: 'I only did it because I love you'
Retaliating against the partner for setting boundaries
behaviors.frequency_note: A single boundary violation can be addressed through conversation and repair. Persistent boundary violations, especially of clearly communicated limits, are a form of disrespect that may constitute emotional or psychological abuse.
common_contexts: Around privacy and personal space
Regarding physical and sexual boundaries
About topics of conversation or interactions with certain people
When one partner's desire conflicts with the other's stated limit
potential_impact: Destroys trust and emotional safety
The violated partner may stop setting boundaries entirely, leading to loss of self
Escalation of violations over time as boundaries are tested and found unenforceable
Can constitute coercive control, particularly when systematic and deliberate
communication_tips: If your boundary is violated, restate it clearly and name the consequence if it happens again
If you have violated a boundary, apologise genuinely and change the behaviour, not just the words
Do not negotiate boundaries in the moment they are being violated; wait until you are both calm
Persistent violation of clearly stated boundaries may require professional support or reconsidering the relationship

behaviors.name: People-Pleasing
behaviors.definition: A pattern of prioritising a partner's needs, desires, and comfort over one's own to an excessive degree, driven by fear of conflict, rejection, or abandonment. Involves chronic self-sacrifice, difficulty saying no, and suppression of authentic feelings and needs.
examples: Always agreeing with your partner even when you have a different opinion
Saying yes to requests even when you are exhausted, overwhelmed, or uncomfortable
Anticipating and meeting your partner's needs before they ask while neglecting your own
Apologising constantly, even for things that are not your fault
healthy_indicators: Being generous and considerate while also honouring your own needs
Saying no when something genuinely does not work for you without excessive guilt
Expressing your authentic opinions even when they differ from your partner's
Recognising the difference between healthy compromise and chronic self-abandonment
unhealthy_indicators: Chronic exhaustion and resentment from overextending yourself
Loss of sense of self; unsure of your own opinions or desires
Terror at the thought of saying no or displeasing your partner
Partner is unaware of your actual feelings because you never express them
behaviors.frequency_note: Occasional accommodation is a healthy part of relationships. People-pleasing becomes problematic when it is the default setting and comes at consistent cost to one's own wellbeing.
common_contexts: When making plans or decisions as a couple
In response to a partner's requests or expressed needs
When conflict is brewing and the people-pleaser tries to prevent it at any cost
In relationships where one partner has become accustomed to having their needs prioritised
potential_impact: Builds deep resentment that eventually surfaces in destructive ways
The relationship loses authenticity as one partner's true self is hidden
The people-pleaser's mental health suffers from chronic self-neglect
Creates an imbalanced dynamic where one partner unknowingly takes more than they give
communication_tips: Start practising small assertions: choosing a restaurant, expressing a preference
Notice and challenge the fear behind the people-pleasing: 'What am I afraid will happen if I say no?'
Your partner deserves to know the real you, including your true opinions and needs
Therapy can be very helpful in understanding and changing long-standing people-pleasing patterns

sources: Gottman, J.M. & Silver, N. (2015). The Seven Principles for Making Marriage Work. Harmony Books.
Johnson, S.M. (2008). Hold Me Tight: Seven Conversations for a Lifetime of Love. Little, Brown Spark.
Bowlby, J. (1988). A Secure Base: Parent-Child Attachment and Healthy Human Development. Basic Books.
Bancroft, L. (2002). Why Does He Do That? Inside the Minds of Angry and Controlling Men. Berkley Books.
Brown, B. (2012). Daring Greatly: How the Courage to Be Vulnerable Transforms the Way We Live, Love, Parent, and Lead. Avery.
Levine, A. & Heller, R. (2010). Attached: The New Science of Adult Attachment. TarcherPerigee.
Chapman, G. (2015). The Five Love Languages: The Secret to Love that Lasts. Northfield Publishing.
Rosenberg, M.B. (2015). Nonviolent Communication: A Language of Life. PuddleDancer Press.
Australian Institute of Family Studies - Research and publications on family relationships
Relationships Australia - Educational resources on healthy relationships
metadata.disclaimer: This behaviour library is designed for educational and self-awareness purposes only. It is not a diagnostic tool and should not be used as a substitute for professional advice from a qualified psychologist, counsellor, or therapist. Relationship dynamics are complex, and individual behaviours should be understood in context rather than in isolation. If you or someone you know is experiencing domestic or family violence, please contact 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732) immediately. If you are in immediate danger, call 000.

australian_resources.1800RESPECT: 1800 737 732 - National domestic violence and sexual assault helpline, available 24/7
australian_resources.Lifeline: 13 11 14 - Crisis support and suicide prevention, available 24/7
australian_resources.Beyond Blue: 1300 22 4636 - Mental health support for anxiety, depression, and wellbeing
australian_resources.Relationships Australia: 1300 364 277 - Relationship support, mediation, and counselling services
australian_resources.MensLine Australia: 1300 78 99 78 - Support for men dealing with relationship and family concerns
australian_resources.Kids Helpline: 1800 55 1800 - Free counselling service for young people aged 5 to 25
australian_resources.QLife: 1800 184 527 - LGBTIQ+ peer support and referral, available 3pm to midnight daily
australian_resources.DV Connect Womensline (QLD): 1800 811 811 - Support for women experiencing domestic and family violence in Queensland
australian_resources.Safe Steps (VIC): 1800 015 188 - 24/7 family violence response centre for Victoria
australian_resources.NSW Domestic Violence Line: 1800 656 463 - 24/7 crisis support for women in New South Wales
australian_resources.Women's Safety Services SA: 1800 800 098 - Domestic and family violence support in South Australia
australian_resources.Crisis Care (WA): 1800 199 008 - After hours crisis support in Western Australia
